conversations.content: You are a skilled librarian specialized in meticulous cataloguing of digital documents.

Task: Extract metadata from a single document and return STRICT JSON ONLY (no prose, no markdown fences, do NOT return the input).

Schema (keys + expectations):
{
  "title": string | null,
  "subtitle": string | null,
  "publication_year": integer | null,            // 4-digit year, e.g., 2022
  "language_as_iso639-2": string | null,         // 3-letter ISO 639-2 code (e.g., "dan", "eng")
  "identifiers": {
    "ISBN": string | null                        // preserve hyphens if present; do not fabricate
  },
  "publisher": string[],                         // array of publisher names; [] if none
  "creator_persons": string[],                   // array of person strings exactly as in text (with roles in []); [] if none
  "creator_corporations": string[],              // array of corporations strings exactly as in text (with roles in []); [] if none
  "country_of_publication_iso639-1": string[],   // 2-letter lowercase ISO 3166-1 codes (e.g., "dk", "se"); [] if unknown
  "series": string[],                            // array of series titles; [] if none
  "series_number": string[]                      // array of series numbering values as strings; [] if none
}

Rules:
- Output ONLY the JSON object with all top-level keys and the "identifiers" key with the subkey "ISBN".
- Do NOT include any extra keys, comments, or text.
- Use null for unknown scalar fields; [] for unknown arrays; {"ISBN": null} if ISBN is missing.
- Normalize:
  - publication_year: single 4-digit year (prefer explicit publication cues).
  - language_as_iso639-2: valid lowercase 3-letter code.
  - country_of_publication_iso639-1: valid lowercase 2-letter codes.
- Do NOT hallucinate values. If multiple possible values exist, choose the one most clearly marked as publication metadata.
- Preserve diacritics in titles/names. Trim whitespace.
- Preserve creator order as in source.

Now process the input strictly per these rules and return the JSON object.

Input:
National Public Health Preparedness
 Outlook Assessment of Response Protocols and Resource Readiness
 Marel Orit


 \nExecutive Summary
 capability assessments reveal uneven readiness bands across modeled jurisdictions with supply-chain resilience
 trending moderate but showing notable gaps in surge distribution logistics

 \nSection 1 Baseline Protocol Review simulated emergency drills indicate variable adherence to triage
 sequencing guidelines and inconsistent activation timing for fictional regional command centers

 \nSection 2 Resource Positioning synthetic inventory maps show clustered stockpiling patterns
  leading to bottlenecks in modeled high-demand corridors during peak-load scenarios

 \nSection 3 Training and Simulation Outcomes scenario runs highlight the value of
 rotational staff-readiness cycles integrated communications rehearsals and distributed decision-support nodes

 \nSection 4 Recommendations synthetic pathways emphasize diversified cache placement periodic readiness
 scoring and iterative protocol refinement

 1998
 Edited by Tilo Envar
 Civic Emergency Planning Unit Health Security Authority
 ISBN 099 9 4444442 9

{"title": "National Public Health Preparedness Outlook", "subtitle": "Assessment of Response Protocols and Resource Readiness", "publication_year": 1998, "language_as_iso639-2": "eng", "identifiers": {"ISBN": "099-9-4444442-9"}, "publisher": ["Health Security Authority"], "creator_persons": ["Marel Orit [author]", "Tilo Envar [editor]"], "creator_corporations": ["Civic Emergency Planning Unit"], "country_of_publication_iso639-1": ["us"]}
You are a skilled librarian specialized in meticulous cataloguing of digital documents.

Schema (keys + expectations):
{
  "title": string | null,

  "publication_year": integer | null,            // 4-digit year, e.g., 2022
  "language_as_iso639-2": string | null,         // 3-letter ISO 639-2 code (e.g., "dan", "eng")
  "identifiers": {
    "ISBN": string | null                        // preserve hyphens if present; do not fabricate
  },
  "publisher": string[],                         // array of publisher names; [] if none
  "creator_persons": string[],                   // array of person strings exactly as in text (with roles in []); [] if none
  "creator_corporations": string[],              // array of corporations strings exactly as in text (with roles in []); [] if none
  "country_of_publication_iso639-1": string[],   // 2-letter lowercase ISO 3166-1 codes (e.g., "dk", "se"); [] if unknown
  "series": string[],                            // array of series titles; [] if none
  "series_number": string[]                      // array of series numbering values as strings; [] if none
}

Rules:
- Output ONLY the JSON object with all top-level keys and the "identifiers" key with the subkey "ISBN".
- Do NOT include any extra keys, comments, or text.
- Use null for unknown scalar fields; [] for unknown arrays; {"ISBN": null} if ISBN is missing.
- Normalize:
  - publication_year: single 4-digit year (prefer explicit publication cues).
  - language_as_iso639-2: valid lowercase 3-letter code.
  - country_of_publication_iso639-1: valid lowercase 2-letter codes.
- Do NOT hallucinate values. If multiple possible values exist, choose the one most clearly marked as publication metadata.
- Preserve diacritics in titles/names. Trim whitespace.
- Preserve creator order as in source.

Now process the input strictly per these rules and return the JSON object.

Input:
Integrated Public Transport Harmonization Plan
 Cross-Regional Scheduling and Service Alignment Proposal


  Rina Velor Daren Solt
    Transit Synchronization Laboratory
  2024
  Intermodal Mobility Coordination Office
   ISBN 099 9 4444441 9\n
   Executive Overview synthetic timetable simulations demonstrate recurring misalignments between modeled rail-to-bus
    connection windows   particularly at fictional transfer hubs with inconsistent dwell buffering\n

Baseline Coordination synthetic network runs show fluctuating throughput on core corridors
     with uneven propagation of delay artifacts when branching services intersect during peak cycles

Alignment Models proposed synthetic harmonization framework tests staggered departure clusters, rotational timing offsets,
and adaptive slack redistribution protocols\nSection 3 Scenario Outcomes modeled results indicate smoother interchange
 continuity and reduced rider wait variance when applying multi-region synchronisation loops

 Implementation Notes recommendations emphasize iterative schedule recalibration
  dynamic dispatch override thresholds   and distributed monitoring agents to trace micro-delay behavior

{"title": "Integrated Public Transport Harmonization Plan", "subtitle": "Cross-Regional Scheduling and Service Alignment Proposal", "publication_year": 2024, "language_as_iso639-2": "eng", "identifiers": {"ISBN": "099-9-4444441-9"}, "publisher": ["Intermodal Mobility Coordination Office"], "creator_persons": ["Rina Velor", "Daren Solt"], "creator_corporations": ["Transit Synchronization Laboratory"], "country_of_publication_iso639-1": ["gb"]}
